[{"text":"{\"path\":\"docs/WEATHERVANE_ESSAY.md\",\"content\":\"# WeatherVane: From Problem Statement to Causal Weather Optimization\\n\\n## Introduction\\nWeatherVane is a platform that helps marketers align advertising budgets with weather-driven demand.\\nThis document intentionally avoids code-level detail and instead narrates the entire system—motivation,\\narchitecture, modelling, user experience, roadmap—so stakeholders can understand what each component\\ndoes, the techniques involved, and why the roadmap priorities matter.\\n\\nThis essay is living documentation; every major enhancement should be reflected here so that non-technical\\nreaders can follow along without jumping across disparate docs.\\n\\n## Problem We Solve\\n- **Marketers struggle to react to weather shifts.** Storms, heatwaves, pollen spikes all influence\\n  consumer behaviour. Today, marketers chase these signals manually or not at all.\\n- **Proving impact is hard.** Without experiments, it’s difficult to show that weather caused lift.\\n- **Budgets are static.** Media plans are often set weeks in advance, ignoring upcoming weather.\\n\\nWeatherVane addresses these issues by ingesting historical sales/ads data, combining it with weather\\nsignals, modelling expected outcomes, and generating recommended ad allocations. We then close the loop\\nvia experiments, calibration, and storytelling so marketers trust the output.\\n\\n## End-to-End Workflow\\n1. **Data ingestion** – connectors pull Shopify orders, Meta/Google/Klaviyo spend, promos.\\n2. **Weather processing** – cache weather history/forecast, compute anomalies and derived features\\n   (temperature, humidity, UV, wind, etc., plus lagged metrics and event flags).\\n3. **Feature store** – join sales/ad data with weather, create modelling matrix.\\n4. **Modelling** – currently LightGBM/heuristics, but roadmap moves us to LightweightMMM + causal IDs.\\n5. **Allocation** – recommend channel/geo budgets with guardrails and uncertainty bands.\\n6. **User experience** – plan hero cards, stories, proof dashboards, onboarding wizard.\\n7. **Feedback loop** – ingest actual outcomes, check calibration, raise alerts when forecasts drift.\\n\\nEach stage relies on a combination of tools (FastAPI, Prefect, Polars, Open-Meteo, MMM libraries) and\\nmethodologies (time-series validation, adstock, saturation, causal inference, quantile coverage). The\\nrest of this doc dives deeper while keeping the narrative accessible.\\n\\n## Roadmap Narrative\\nWe maintain a delivery roadmap (see `docs/ROADMAP.md`) taking WeatherVane from proof-of-concept to\\nproduction-ready solution. Highlights:\\n- **Phase 0** – Prove value (A/B experiments, calibration, disclaimers).\\n- **Phase 1** – UX overhaul (demo mode, hero insights, proof surfacing).\\n- **Phase 2** – Feedback loop (performance tracker, forecast alerts).\\n- **Phase 3** – Connector platform (SDK, onboarding).\\n- **Phase 4** – MMM + causal upgrades (LightweightMMM, DoWhy/EconML, spatial models).\\n- ... and so on through automation, security, interoperability.\\n\\nThis essay will reference relevant phases as we discuss each subsystem.\\n\\n## Data Ingestion & Weather Signals\\nWeatherVane ingests ecommerce and marketing platforms (Shopify, Meta, Google, Klaviyo) via connectors.\\nWeather data comes from Open-Meteo. We cache responses, compute climatology, and now include rhythms like\\nhumidity, UV, wind, precipitation probability, snowfall, etc., plus lagged metrics and event flags.\\nThese features help MMM and causal analyses understand lagged demand (stockpiling before a storm, etc.).\\n\\n## Modelling Strategy (Layman’s Breakdown)\\n- **Today:** LightGBM models with heuristic elasticity. Quantile outputs propagate uncertainty.\\n- **Tomorrow (Phase 4):** LightweightMMM or Robyn adds adstock (delayed effects) and saturation (diminishing returns).\\n- **Causal ID:** Difference-in-differences across geos, instrumental variables (forecast errors) to prove causal impact.\\n- **Explainability:** SHAP values, counterfactuals, hierarchical splits (brand vs performance), and forecast coverage dashboards.\\n\\nEach technique will be introduced in plain English when implemented (e.g., “adstock is like keeping track of how long people remember an ad”).\\n\\n## Allocation & Guardrails\\nThe allocator uses recommended response curves to suggest how much to spend per channel/geo. Guardrails\\nensure we don’t violate ROAS floors, ramp limits, inventory constraints. Phase 4 upgrades will allow\\nthe allocator to consume MMM response curves directly rather than heuristic elasticities.\\n\\n## UX & Trust Journey\\n- **Problem:** Users previously saw empty states. No proof, no value.\\n- **Actions:** Demo mode, onboarding wizard, plan hero cards, proof nav, success toasts.\\n- **Result:** Time-to-first-value (TTV) goes from “infinite” to <60s with sample data. Proof page clearly shows experiments and forecast reliability.\\n\\n## Feedback & Observability\\nWe built a performance tracker that logs MAE/MAPE and quantile coverage per horizon. CLI option\\n`--alert-forecast` warns when p10–p90 coverage drops below threshold. Observability metrics feed dashboards.\\n\\n## Security & Compliance Summary\\nRetention sweeps, consent tracking, privacy endpoints exist today. Roadmap includes vault migration, rates\\nlimits, SOC2 prep.\\n\\n## Future Vision\\nFull causal MMM, automation (push recommended budgets automatically), cross-tool integrations (Salesforce, Energy),\\nand even weather derivatives for financial hedging.\\n\\n---\\n\\n### Maintaining this Essay\\n- When new features ship (e.g., MMM integration, causal experiments), update the relevant sections.\\n- Keep references to roadmap phases so stakeholders know what’s done and what’s in progress.\\n- Ensure non-technical language mirrors the actual implementation.\\n\\n\"}","type":"text"}]

__future__ import annotations\\n\\nfrom dataclasses import dataclass\\nfrom datetime import datetime\\nfrom pathlib import Path\\nfrom typing import Dict\\n\\nimport polars as pl\\n\\nfrom \\\"precip_roll7\\\",\\n}\\n\\n\\n@dataclass\\nclass FeatureMatrix:\\n    frame: pl.DataFrame\\n    orders_rows: int\\n    ads_rows: int\\n    promo_rows: int\\n    weather_rows: int\\n    profiles: \\\"geohash\\\" in orders_daily.columns\\n            and \\\"geohash\\\" in weather_daily.columns\\n            and not orders_daily.get_column(\\\"geohash\\\").is_null().all()\\n            and not how=\\\"left\\\")\\n        else:\\n            frame = weather_daily\\n\\n        frame = frame.with_columns(pl.col(\\\"date\\\").cast(pl.Utf8))\\n\\n        ads_join = ads_daily.drop([col for col in on=\\\"date\\\", how=\\\"full\\\", suffix=\\\"_promo\\\")\\n        if \\\"date_promo\\\" in frame.columns:\\n            frame = frame.drop(\\\"date_promo\\\")\\n        frame = frame.sort(\\\"date\\\").fill_null(0)\\n        start_str = start.date().isoformat()\\n        end_str = end.date().isoformat()\\n        frame = frame.filter(pl.col(\\\"date\\\").is_between(pl.lit(start_str), pl.lit(end_str)))\\n\\n        missing = [col for col in REQUIRED_WEATHER_COLS if col not in frame.columns]\\n        if missing:\\n Exception:  # pragma: no cover - profiling is best-effort\\n            profiles = {}\\n\\n        return FeatureMatrix(\\n            frame=frame,\\n            orders_rows=int(orders.height),\\n )\\n\\n    def _load_latest(self, dataset: str) -> pl.DataFrame:\\n        path = self.writer.latest(dataset)\\n        if not path:\\n            return pl.DataFrame([])\\n        return read_parquet(path)\\n\\n    def _orders_daily(self, orders: pl.DataFrame) -> pl.DataFrame:\\n        if orders.is_empty():\\n            return pl.DataFrame({\\\"date\\\": [], \\\"geohash\\\": [], \\\"net_revenue\\\": []})\\n        if \\\"created_at\\\" not in orders.columns:\\n            raise ValueError(\\\"orders dataset missing `created_at`\\\")\\n        frame = orders.with_columns([\\n            pl.col(\\\"created_at\\\").str.slice(0, 10).alias(\\\"date\\\"),\\n            pl.col(\\\"ship_geohash\\\").alias(\\\"geohash\\\"),\\n        ])\\n        group_cols = [\\\"date\\\", \\\"geohash\\\"] if \\\"ship_geohash\\\" in orders.columns else [\\\"date\\\"]\\n        return frame.group_by(group_cols).agg(pl.col(\\\"net_revenue\\\").sum())\\n\\n    def _ads_daily(self, meta: pl.DataFrame, google: pl.DataFrame) -> pl.DataFrame:\\n        frames = []\\n        if not meta.is_empty():\\n            frames.append(\\n                meta.with_columns(pl.col(\\\"date\\\").alias(\\\"date\\\"))\\n                .group_by(\\\"date\\\")\\n                .agg([\\n                    pl.col(\\\"spend\\\").sum().alias(\\\"meta_spend\\\"),\\n                    pl.col(\\\"conversions\\\").sum().alias(\\\"meta_conversions\\\"),\\n                ])\\n                .with_columns(pl.lit(\\\"GLOBAL\\\").alias(\\\"geohash\\\"))\\n            )\\n        if not google.is_empty():\\n            frames.append(\\n                google.with_columns(pl.col(\\\"date\\\").alias(\\\"date\\\"))\\n                .group_by(\\\"date\\\")\\n                .agg([\\n                    pl.col(\\\"spend\\\").sum().alias(\\\"google_spend\\\"),\\n                    pl.col(\\\"conversions\\\").sum().alias(\\\"google_conversions\\\"),\\n                ])\\n                .with_columns(pl.lit(\\\"GLOBAL\\\").alias(\\\"geohash\\\"))\\n            )\\n        if not frames:\\n            return pl.DataFrame({\\n                \\\"date\\\": [],\\n                \\\"geohash\\\": [],\\n                \\\"meta_spend\\\": [],\\n                \\\"meta_conversions\\\": [],\\n                \\\"google_spend\\\": [],\\n                \\\"google_conversions\\\": [],\\n            })\\n        return (\\n            pl.concat(frames, how=\\\"align\\\")\\n            .group_by(\\\"date\\\")\\n            .agg([\\n                pl.col(\\\"meta_spend\\\").sum(),\\n                pl.col(\\\"meta_conversions\\\").sum(),\\n                pl.col(\\\"google_spend\\\").sum(),\\n                pl.col(\\\"google_conversions\\\").sum(),\\n            ])\\n            .with_columns(pl.lit(\\\"GLOBAL\\\").alias(\\\"geohash\\\"))\\n        )\\n\\n    def _promos_daily(self, promos: pl.DataFrame) -> pl.DataFrame:\\n        if promos.is_empty():\\n            return pl.DataFrame({\\\"date\\\": [], \\\"geohash\\\": [], \\\"promos_sent\\\": []})\\n        col = \\\"send_date\\\" if \\\"send_date\\\" in promos.columns else \\\"scheduled_at\\\"\\n        return (\\n            promos\\n            .with_columns(pl.col(col).str.slice(0, 10).alias(\\\"date\\\"))\\n            .group_by(\\\"date\\\")\\n            .agg(pl.len().alias(\\\"promos_sent\\\"))\\n            .with_columns(pl.lit(\\\"GLOBAL\\\").alias(\\\"geohash\\\"))\\n        )\\n\\n    def _weather_daily(self, weather: pl.DataFrame) -> pl.DataFrame:\\n        if weather.is_empty():\\n            return pl.DataFrame({\\n                \\\"date\\\": [],\\n                \\\"geohash\\\": [],\\n                \\\"temp_c\\\": [],\\n                \\\"precip_mm\\\": [],\\n                \\\"temp_anomaly\\\": [],\\n                \\\"precip_anomaly\\\": [],\\n                \\\"temp_roll7\\\": [],\\n                \\\"precip_roll7\\\": [],\\n            })\\n        missing = REQUIRED_WEATHER_COLS - set(weather.columns)\\n        if missing:\\n            raise ValueError(f\\\"Weather dataset missing columns: {missing}\\\")\\n        frame = weather.with_columns(\\n            pl.col(\\\"date\\\").str.strptime(pl.Date, strict=False).alias(\\\"date\\\"),\\n        )\\n        frame = frame.sort([\\\"geohash\\\", \\\"date\\\"])\\n        frame = frame.with_columns(\\n            pl.col(\\\"temp_c\\\")\\n            .rolling_mean(window_size=7, min_samples=3)\\n            .over(\\\"geohash\\\")\\n            .alias(\\\"temp_roll7\\\"),\\n            pl.col(\\\"precip_mm\\\")\\n            .rolling_mean(window_size=7, min_samples=3)\\n            .over(\\\"geohash\\\")\\n            .alias(\\\"precip_roll7\\\"),\\n        )\\n        frame = frame.with_columns(pl.col(\\\"date\\\").cast(pl.Utf8))\\n        return frame\\n\"}","type":"text"}]

\\\"coverage_below_threshold\\\" and failing:\\n            message = {\\n                \\\"tenant_id\\\": args.tenant,\\n                \\\"status\\\": summary[\\\"status\\\"],\\n                \\\"failing_horizons\\\": failing,\\n                \\\"coverage\\\": summary[\\\"summary\\\"][\\\"coverage\\\"],\\n            }\\n            print(json.dumps({\\\"alert\\\": message}, indent=2, sort_keys=True))\\n            _append_log(args.log_file, \\\"forecast.alert\\\", message)\\n        else:\\n            print(json.dumps({\\\"alert\\\": \\\"ok\\\", \\\"tenant_id\\\": args.tenant}, indent=2, sort_keys=True))\\n        return\\n\\n    if args.retention_report:\\n        if not args.retention_summary_root:\\n            raise SystemExit(\\\"--retention-summary-root is required print(json.dumps(summary, indent=2, sort_keys=True))\\n        if args.export_observability:\\n            report = load_retention_report_full(args.retention_summary_root)\\n            export_retention_report(report, args.export_observability)\\n            print(f\\\"[observability] wrote retention report to {args.export_observability}\\\")\\n        _append_log(args.log_file, \\\"retention.report\\\", summary)\\n        return\\n\\n    if args.smoke_test:\\n        summary = run_smoke_test_sync(\\n            args.tenant,\\n            start_date=_parse_datetime(args.start),\\n            end_date=_parse_datetime(args.end),\\n        )\\n        print(json.dumps(summary.to_dict(), indent=2, sort_keys=True))\\n        if args.export_observability and args.retention_summary_root:\\n            retention = load_retention_report_full(args.retention_summary_root)\\n            geocoding = load_geocoding_reports(args.retention_summary_root)\\n            export_retention_report(retention, Path(args.export_observability).with_name(\\\"retention.json\\\"))\\n            export_geocoding_reports(geocoding, Path(args.export_observability).with_name(\\\"geocoding.json\\\"))\\n            print(f\\\"[observability] wrote telemetry to _run_retention(args)\\n        print(\\\"[weathervane-worker] Retention sweep complete\\\")\\n        if result:\\n            print(result)\\n        return\\n\\n    if args.all_tenants or retention_result = _run_retention(args)\\n        print(\\\"[weathervane-worker] Retention sweep complete\\\")\\n        if retention_result:\\n            print(retention_result)\\n\\n\\nif __name__ == \\\"__main__\\\":\\n    main()\\n\"}","type":"text"}]

payload.text:
**Designing weather data blending approach**

I’m mapping out how to blend historical and forecast weather into one aligned dataset, figuring out timezones per location and how to handle date conversions without breaking existing code. I’m planning a new module to fetch and combine data carefully, making sure to distinguish observed vs. forecast data and keep timezone info aligned for proper joins downstream.

**Planning timezone-consistent weather blending**

I’m working through how to ensure both historical and forecast weather fetches use the same timezone—likely by passing `timezone=auto`—so their data aligns properly. This means updating data loading to include timezone info, enhancing internal methods to create timezone-aware dates, and distinguishing observed versus forecast records in the combined dataset.

**Designing weather blending module and pipeline integration**

I’m outlining a new `WeatherBlender` class that combines observed and forecast weather data into a unified, timezone-consistent dataset with metadata. This involves adding helper methods, crafting a dataclass result, updating caching and fetch methods with timezone awareness, and modifying the pipeline fetch task to use this blender with a forecast horizon. I’m also planning thorough tests using stub connectors to verify correct blending and timezone handling.

**Refining weather data handling and schema updates**

I’m focusing on ensuring uniqueness includes observation type to avoid losing forecast data, enhancing fallback stubs to emit all required schema fields with consistent timezone info, and updating the JSON schema to include new columns like `local_date`, `observation_type`, and `as_of_utc`. I’m also planning to extend documentation and context records to reflect these changes, plus running thorough test and quality checks before marking the roadmap update complete.

frames.append(forecast_frame.with_columns(pl.lit(\\\"forecast\\\").alias(\\\"__source\\\")))\\n\\n        combined = self._combine_frames(frames)\\n        return self._frame_to_payload(\\n daily = {\\\"time\\\": [], \\\"observation_type\\\": []}\\n        else:\\n            if \\\"observation_type\\\" not in frame.columns:\\n                frame = frame.with_columns(pl.lit(\\\"observed\\\").alias(\\\"observation_type\\\"))\\n            frame = frame.sort([\\\"date\\\", \\\"geohash\\\"])\\n            dates = .otherwise(pl.col(\\\"observation_type\\\"))\\n            .alias(\\\"observation_type\\\")\\n        )\\n        combined = combined.drop([\\\"__priority\\\"], strict=False)\\n        return **Updating timezone handling in ensure_range**

I’m adjusting the `ensure_range` method to include the timezone name properly in its return values. Since cached payloads don’t have `params`, I’ll extract the timezone from the payload or default to "UTC" there, while for fresh fetches I can still check both the response and params for the timezone before defaulting. This should ensure the timezone is set consistently in the `WeatherFetchResult`.

payload.text:
**Ensuring complete fallback data and updating tests**

I’m verifying the fallback row includes all required columns, like `humidity_mean` and `observation_type`, while clarifying which climatology fields are necessary. I’m also planning to enhance the test stub to implement both `fetch_forecast` and `fetch_archive`, simulating different date ranges and timezones. To test blended forecasts properly, I need to monkeypatch the static `_local_today` method to control “current” dates during tests, ensuring coverage of both observed and forecast data. Finally, I’ll update test assertions to check new columns and observation type counts.

To test blended forecasts properly, I need to monkeypatch the static `_local_today` method to control “current” dates during tests, ensuring coverage of both observed and forecast data. Finally, I’ll update test assertions to check new columns and observation type counts.

+import pytest
+
+import geohash2  # type: ignore
+
+from shared.feature_store.weather_cache import WeatherCache
+from shared.libs.connectors.weather import WeatherConnector
+from shared.observability import metrics
+from shared.validation.schemas import validate_weather_daily
+
+
+class StubWeatherConnector(WeatherConnector):
+    def __init__(self) -> None:  # type: ignore[override]
+        pass
+
+    async def fetch_forecast(self, lat: float, lon: float, **params):  # type: ignore[override]
+        return self._build_payload(params, label="forecast")
+
+    async def fetch_archive(self, lat: float, lon: float, **params):  # type: ignore[override]
+        return self._build_payload(params, label="archive")
+
+    def _build_payload(self, params: dict[str, object], label: str) -> dict[str, object]:
+        timezone_name = str(params.get("timezone") or "UTC")
+        start = date.fromisoformat(str(params["start_date"]))
+        end = date.fromisoformat(str(params["end_date"]))
+        length = (end - start).days + 1
+        days = [start + timedelta(days=i) for i in range(length)]
+        temps = [10 + i for i in range(length)]
+        return {
+            "timezone": timezone_name,
+            "utc_offset_seconds": 0,
+            "daily_units": {},
+            "daily": {
+                "time": [day.isoformat() for day in days],
+                "temperature_2m_mean": temps,
+                "temperature_2m_max": [value + 2 for value in temps],
+                "temperature_2m_min": [value - 2 for value in temps],
+                "apparent_temperature_mean": temps,
+                "precipitation_sum": [float(i) for i in range(length)],
+                "precipitation_probability_max": [50 + i * 5 for i in range(length)],
+                "relative_humidity_2m_mean": [60 + i for i in range(length)],
+                "windspeed_10m_max": [20 + i for i in range(length)],
+                "uv_index_max": [4 + i for i in range(length)],
+                "snowfall_sum": [0.0] * length,
+                "observation_type": [label] * length,
+            },
+        }
*** End Patch

payload.arguments:
{"path":"docs/weather/blending.md","content":"# Weather Blending Guide

WeatherVane needs a single, stitch-free timeline of weather metrics that covers both
historical observations and forward-looking forecasts. This guide explains how the
`WeatherCache` blends Open-Meteo archive data with forecast responses, keeps timezones
honest, and exposes the metadata modelling and UX layers rely on.

## Key behaviours

- **Dual-source fetches.** `WeatherCache.ensure_range` now orchestrates two upstream
  calls when the requested window spans today: the Open-Meteo archive API provides
  observed history up through "yesterday" while the forecast endpoint fills future
days. Overlapping days prefer archive observations and drop forecast duplicates.
- **Timezone alignment.** All requests default to `timezone=auto`. Responses are
  normalised into four columns: `local_date`, `local_datetime`, `utc_datetime`, and
  `timezone`. We leverage `zoneinfo` so midnight boundaries always reflect the local
  clock for each geohash, but we also persist UTC strings for joins with Shopify and
  ads datasets.
- **Observation provenance.** Each row carries an `observation_type` flag
  (`observed`, `forecast`, or `stub` for synthetic fallbacks) plus an `as_of_utc`
  timestamp documenting when WeatherVane generated the record. Analytics can now
  separate realised weather from forward-looking signals, and front-end charts can
  label forecast horizons explicitly.
- **Contract update.** The daily weather schema (`shared/contracts/weather_daily.schema.json`)
  was expanded to cover the new timezone and provenance fields while keeping
  `additionalProperties=false`. Data quality checks (`validate_weather_daily`) enforce
  the contract before anything hits the lake.

## Usage notes

- The worker pipeline extends each tenant's weather request by
  `FORECAST_HORIZON_DAYS` (currently seven). Historical modelling still filters to the
  requested end date, while allocation and UX layers can read the forward span for
  opportunity cards.
- Cached payloads store the blended response (`generated_at`, units, timezone, and
  per-day observation types). Re-fetching a range pulls directly from disk with the
  same schema, so repeated runs are deterministic and fast.
- Synthetic fallbacks populate the extended schema, allowing local development without
  live API credentials.

Refer to `apps/worker/flows/poc_pipeline.py::fetch_weather_data` for an example of the
blended output feeding downstream joins and telemetry.
"}

{"output":"# Ingestion Playbook

This guide explains how to add or modify ingestion tasks. The goals:
- Every source looks the same (easy to read, easy to debug)
- Junior engineers can copy/paste an existing pattern
- The Prefect flow remains clean and declarative

## Core Concepts

| Component | Location | Responsibility |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `BaseIngestor`, `IngestionSummary` | `apps/worker/ingestion/base.py` | Shared helpers and return type (path + row count + source + metadata) |
| Connector wrappers | `shared/libs/connectors` | Handle raw HTTP/gRPC calls (pagination, retries, OAuth refresh) |
| Ingester modules | `apps/worker/ingestion/<source>.py` | Normalise records and store Parquet snapshots |
| Storage utilities | `shared/libs/storage/lake.py` | Write/read Parquet via Polars (single entry point) |
| Prefect flows | `apps/worker/flows/*.py` | Call ingestors, log summaries, feed modelling tasks |

## Adding a New Ingester

1. Create `apps/worker/ingestion/<source>.py`.
   - Import `BaseIngestor`, `IngestionSummary`, and the relevant connector/config.
   - Normalise API responses into flat dictionaries (no nested JSON in Parquet).
   - Call `self._write_records(dataset, rows, source=...)` to persist results.
   - Return `IngestionSummary`.
2. Write tests under `tests/test_<source>_ingestion.py` using stub connectors.
   - Verify the ingestor writes Parquet and returns the correct row count.
3. Update Prefect flow (`poc_pipeline.py`) to call the new ingestor.
   - Keep the task wrapper small; it should focus on logging and returning summaries.
4. Document any required environment variables in this file and `docs/STACK.md` if needed.
5. Persist incremental state using `JsonStateStore` when the source supports cursors (for example `updated_at_min`).

## Environment Variables (Shopify example)
```
SHOPIFY_SHOP_DOMAIN=<my-shop.myshopify.com>
SHOPIFY_ACCESS_TOKEN=<admin api token>
SHOPIFY_API_VERSION=2024-04  # optional
# Optional, used for OAuth token refresh
SHOPIFY_CLIENT_ID=<oauth client id>
SHOPIFY_CLIENT_SECRET=<oauth client secret>
SHOPIFY_REFRESH_TOKEN=<oauth refresh token>
```
If an environment variable is missing, the task deliberately falls back to stub data for local
prototyping. This behaviour is visible in the logs and the returned `source` field.

## Pagination & Rate Limits
- `DEFAULT_PAGE_LIMIT` keeps requests small; adjust if Shopify introduces new limits.
- For other connectors, implement exponential backoff or rate limiting if required.
- Store the raw `next_page_info` (or equivalent token) in your loop to avoid infinite paging.

## Meta Ads
- Graph API base URL is `https://graph.facebook.com/<graph_version>`.
- The connector follows `paging.cursors.after` (or parses `paging.next`) until exhausted.
- Automatic retries/backoff leverage the shared HTTP connector; plug in `AsyncRateLimiter` to stay under burst limits.
- On HTTP 401 the connector exchanges the short-lived token using `app_id`/`app_secret` and updates headers transparently.

Environment variables:

```
META_ACCESS_TOKEN=<short-lived or long-lived token>
META_APP_ID=<facebook app id>
META_APP_SECRET=<facebook app secret>
META_GRAPH_VERSION=v19.0
```

Persist the refreshed token to your secrets store if you want subsequent runs to reuse it; otherwise
the connector refreshes in-memory whenever Meta invalidates the token.

## Google Ads
- REST endpoint base: `https://googleads.googleapis.com/<version>/customers/{cid}/googleAds:search`.
- Requests are POST with GAQL queries; the connector handles `nextPageToken` pagination and yields rows via `search_iter`.
- Retries/backoff use the shared HTTP connector; add an async rate limiter to respect QPS caps.
- On HTTP 401 the connector exchanges the refresh token for a new access token (`oauth2.googleapis.com/token`) and updates headers.

Environment variables / secrets:

```
GOOGLE_ADS_DEVELOPER_TOKEN=<developer token>
GOOGLE_ADS_CLIENT_ID=<oauth client id>
GOOGLE_ADS_CLIENT_SECRET=<oauth client secret>
GOOGLE_ADS_REFRESH_TOKEN=<oauth refresh token>
GOOGLE_ADS_LOGIN_CUSTOMER_ID=<manager customer id, optional>
GOOGLE_ADS_ACCESS_TOKEN=<optional bootstrap access token>
GOOGLE_ADS_API_VERSION=v14
```

For local smoke tests you can omit `GOOGLE_ADS_ACCESS_TOKEN`; the connector will immediately refresh using the
refresh token. Persist refreshed tokens centrally if you want to avoid repeated token exchanges across runs.

## Geocoding validation
- Orders ingestion stores `ship_geohash` alongside the raw record and writes `geocoded_ratio` into the ingestion summary.
- The helper `apps.worker.validation.geocoding.evaluate_geocoding_coverage` loads the latest orders snapshot, computes coverage, and persists a JSON report under `storage/metadata/state/geocoding/<tenant>.json`.
- Coverage results bubble into the PoC pipeline response (`geocoding_validation`) and inform context tags (e.g. `geo.partial`, `geo.missing`).
- Default threshold is 0.8; adjust per tenant if you expect higher sparsity.

## Why Parquet + LakeWriter?
- Every ingestor writes via `LakeWriter.write_records(dataset, rows)`.
- Datasets live under `storage/lake/raw/<tenant_dataset>/<timestamp>.parquet`.
- Downstream tasks always load the **latest** snapshot for modelling.

## Quick Recipe for a New Source
```python
@dataclass
class MySourceIngestor(BaseIngestor):
    connector: MySourceConnector

    async def ingest(self, tenant_id: str) -> IngestionSummary:
        payloads = await self.connector.fetch(...)
        rows = [self._normalise(item) for item in payloads]
        metrics = {"geocoded_ratio": 0.94}
        return self._write_records(
            f"{tenant_id}_mysource",
            rows,
            source="mysource_api",
            metadata=metrics,
        )
```

Keep things boring and explicit—future contributors will have a much easier time.


## Weather Cache
- Weather fetches are keyed by tenant shipping geohashes (derived from order-level geocoding).
- Daily metrics stored under `storage/lake/weather/<geohash>/...json` with a running climatology in `climatology.parquet`.
- Anomalies are computed against day-of-year climatology so downstream models receive stationarised weather deltas.
- Rolling seven-day means (`temp_roll7`, `precip_roll7`) provide smoother signals for multi-geo aggregation.
- Feature builder expects columns `temp_c`, `precip_mm`, `temp_anomaly`, `precip_anomaly`, `temp_roll7`, `precip_roll7`.
- Schema validation runs via `shared.validation.schemas`.
","metadata":{"exit_code":0,"duration_seconds":0.0}}

- Schema validation runs via `shared.validation.schemas`.

### Open-Meteo Daily Weather

`WeatherCache.ensure_range` produces frames validated against `shared/contracts/weather_daily.schema.json`.

| Field | Type | Notes |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `date` | string | UTC calendar date used for joins with other datasets |
| `local_date` | string | Local (timezone-aware) calendar date returned by Open-Meteo |
| `local_datetime` | string | Local midnight timestamp with timezone offset |
| `utc_datetime` | string | UTC timestamp corresponding to local midnight |
| `timezone` | string | IANA timezone identifier (e.g. `America/Los_Angeles`) |
| `geohash` | string | Precision `5` cell linking back to tenant geo |
| `temp_c`, `precip_mm` | number | Primary signals used downstream |
| `temp_anomaly`, `precip_anomaly` | number | Deviations vs climatology |
| `temp_roll7`, `precip_roll7` | number/null | Rolling seven-day means (null for the warmup window) |
| `*_lag1` columns | number/null | Previous-day values for leading indicators |
| `freeze_flag`, `heatwave_flag`, `snow_event_flag`, `high_wind_flag`, `uv_alert_flag`, `high_precip_prob_flag` | integer | Binary threshold events used in downstream feature builders |
| `observation_type` | string | `observed`, `forecast`, or `stub` provenance tag |
| `as_of_utc` | string | Timestamp when WeatherVane generated the blended row |

Daily frames keep additional context columns (`temp_max_c`, `humidity_mean`, `uv_index_max`, etc.) so feature engineering can remain declarative.

plug in `AsyncRateLimiter` to stay under burst limits.\\n- On HTTP 401 the connector exchanges the short-lived token using `app_id`/`app_secret` and updates headers transparently.\\n\\nEnvironment variables:\\n\\n```\\nMETA_ACCESS_TOKEN=<short-lived or long-lived token>\\nMETA_APP_ID=<facebook app id>\\nMETA_APP_SECRET=<facebook app secret>\\nMETA_GRAPH_VERSION=v19.0\\n```\\n\\nPersist the refreshed token to your secrets store if you want subsequent runs to reuse it; otherwise\\nthe connector refreshes in-memory whenever Meta invalidates the token.\\n\\n## Google Ads\\n- REST endpoint base: `https://googleads.googleapis.com/<version>/customers/{cid}/googleAds:search`.\\n- Requests are POST with GAQL queries; the connector handles `nextPageToken` pagination and yields rows via `search_iter`.\\n- Retries/backoff use the shared HTTP connector; add an async rate limiter to respect QPS caps.\\n- On HTTP 401 the connector exchanges the refresh token for a new access token (`oauth2.googleapis.com/token`) and updates headers.\\n\\nEnvironment variables / secrets:\\n\\n```\\nGOOGLE_ADS_DEVELOPER_TOKEN=<developer token>\\nGOOGLE_ADS_CLIENT_ID=<oauth client id>\\nGOOGLE_ADS_CLIENT_SECRET=<oauth client secret>\\nGOOGLE_ADS_REFRESH_TOKEN=<oauth refresh token>\\nGOOGLE_ADS_LOGIN_CUSTOMER_ID=<manager customer id, optional>\\nGOOGLE_ADS_ACCESS_TOKEN=<optional bootstrap access token>\\nGOOGLE_ADS_API_VERSION=v14\\n```\\n\\nFor local smoke tests you can omit `GOOGLE_ADS_ACCESS_TOKEN`; the connector will immediately refresh using the\\nrefresh token. Persist refreshed tokens centrally if you want to avoid repeated token exchanges across runs.\\n\\n## Geocoding validation\\n- Orders ingestion stores `ship_geohash` alongside the raw record and writes `geocoded_ratio` into the ingestion summary.\\n- The helper `apps.worker.validation.geocoding.evaluate_geocoding_coverage` loads the latest orders snapshot, computes coverage, and persists a JSON report under `storage/metadata/state/geocoding/<tenant>.json`.\\n- Coverage results bubble into the PoC pipeline response (`geocoding_validation`) and inform context tags (e.g. `geo.partial`, `geo.missing`).\\n- Default threshold is 0.8; adjust per tenant if you expect higher sparsity.\\n\\n## Why Parquet + LakeWriter?\\n- Every ingestor writes via `LakeWriter.write_records(dataset, rows)`.\\n- Datasets live under `storage/lake/raw/<tenant_dataset>/<timestamp>.parquet`.\\n- Downstream tasks always load the **latest** snapshot for modelling.\\n\\n## Quick Recipe for a New Source\\n```python\\n@dataclass\\nclass MySourceIngestor(BaseIngestor):\\n    connector: MySourceConnector\\n\\n    async def ingest(self, tenant_id: str) -> IngestionSummary:\\n        payloads = await my_connector.fetch(...)\\n        rows = [self._normalise(item) for item in payloads]\\n        metrics = {\\\"geocoded_ratio\\\": 0.94}\\n        return self._write_records(\\n            f\\\"{tenant_id}_mysource\\\",\\n            rows,\\n            source=\\\"mysource_api\\\",\\n            metadata=metrics,\\n        )\\n```\\n\\nKeep things boring and explicit—future contributors will have a much easier time.\\n\\n\\n## Weather Cache\\n- Weather fetches are keyed by tenant shipping geohashes (derived from order-level geocoding).\\n- Daily metrics stored under `storage/lake/weather/<geohash>/...json` with a running climatology in `climatology.parquet`.\\n- Anomalies are computed against day-of-year climatology so downstream models receive stationarised weather deltas.\\n- Rolling seven-day means (`temp_roll7`, `precip_roll7`) provide smoother signals for multi-geo aggregation.\\n- Feature builder expects columns `temp_c`, `precip_mm`, `temp_anomaly`, `precip_anomaly`, `temp_roll7`, `precip_roll7`.\\n- Schema validation runs via `shared.validation.schemas`.\\n\\n### Open-Meteo Daily Weather\\n\\n`WeatherCache.ensure_range` produces frames validated against `shared/contracts/weather_daily.schema.json`.\\n\\n| Field | Type | Notes |\\n| --- | --- | --- |\\n| `date` | string | UTC calendar date used for joins with other datasets |\\n| `local_date` | string | Local (timezone-aware) calendar date returned by Open-Meteo |\\n| `local_datetime` | string | Local midnight timestamp with timezone offset |\\n| `utc_datetime` | string | UTC timestamp corresponding to local midnight |\\n| `timezone` | string | IANA timezone identifier (e.g. `America/Los_Angeles`) |\\n| `geohash` | string | Precision `5` cell linking back to tenant geo |\\n| `temp_c`, `precip_mm` | number | Primary signals used downstream |\\n| `temp_anomaly`, `precip_anomaly` | number | Deviations vs climatology |\\n| `temp_roll7`, `precip_roll7` | number/null | Rolling seven-day means (null for the warmup window) |\\n| `*_lag1` columns | number/null | Previous-day values for leading indicators |\\n| `freeze_flag`, `heatwave_flag`, `snow_event_flag`, `high_wind_flag`, `uv_alert_flag`, `high_precip_prob_flag` | integer | Binary threshold events used in downstream feature builders |\\n| `observation_type` | string | `observed`, `forecast`, or `stub` provenance tag |\\n| `as_of_utc` | string | Timestamp when WeatherVane generated the blended row |\\n\\nDaily frames keep additional context columns (`temp_max_c`, `humidity_mean`, `uv_index_max`, etc.) so feature engineering can remain declarative.\\n\\n\"}","type":"text"}]

- Extended `WeatherCache` to stitch Open-Meteo archive + forecast responses with timezone-aware timestamps, provenance tags, and `as_of_utc` metadata; pipeline now requests a 7-day horizon and dedupes by `date`/`geohash`/`observation_type`.

Next actions:
- Verify downstream feature builder respects new columns and flags (already validated via targeted test); monitor production run for unexpected forecast alignment issues.

**Reviewing lint issues and test strategy**

I'm noticing that running ruff on the whole repo reveals many pre-existing lint problems, which likely explains the original error and why the lint target limits errors. Since we can't fix all these now, I'll document the deprecation and lint errors in the summary. I'll also try running make test next to confirm test behavior despite potential warnings or failures.
